results.title: Les Grandes Gueules = the Big Shots
results.brief_description:
After years of exile in Canada, Hector Valentin comes back to his village in the Vosges mountains to manage his father’s sawmill. He gives jobs to Laurent and Mick, two locals who suggest Hector should employed released convicts. Hector accepts the proposal without realising this is part of a plan to have Rechtman, a famous gangster, released and eliminated.

Credits: Producer, Michel Ardan ; director, Robert Enrico ; writers, Robert Enrico, Jose Giovanni ; photography, Jean Boffetty ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Bourvil, Lino Ventura, Jean-Claude Rolland, Marie Dubois, Jess Hahn, Pierre Frag, Michel Constantin, Marcel Peres, Paul Crauchet, Nick Stephanini.

results.title: Regain = Harvest
results.brief_description:
A poacher, wishing for fatherhood, coaxes an itinerant girl away from her simple knifegrinder companion and sets up house with her in a deserted village which they bring back to life. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide. A darker side to Marcel Pagnol’s work drew on an older Mediterranean culture, that of the rural drama reflected in ‘Jofroi’ (1933), ‘Angele’ (1934) and ‘Regain/Harvest’ (1937). These melodramas were grounded in the same archaic patriarchal values as the trilogy, but they swapped theatricality for location shooting and have been recognised as influential on neo-realism.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Willy ; music, Arthur Honegger.
Cast: Gabriel Gabrio, Fernandel, Orane Demazis, Edouard Delmont, Marguerite Moreno, Robert Le Vigan.

results.title: Rak
results.brief_description:
A elderly woman of Russian origin is informed that she is stricken with cancer (‘rak’ in Russian). She is determined to fight the disease and live. She must also fight the inertia and indifference of the medical staff and of the administrative system supposed to look after her. In the light of her experiences, her son David decides to care for her at home and do everything possible to make her last days the happiest.

Credits: Director, Charles Belmont ; writers, Charles Belmont ; photography, Jean-Jacques Rochut ; music, Andre Hodeir.
Cast: Sami Frey, Lila Kedrova, Anne Deleuze, Maurice Garrel, Philippe Leotard.

results.title: L'oeil du Malin = the Third Lover
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Carlo Ponti and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
A second-rate French journalist visiting West Germany to write a series of articles meets a successful author and his French wife, who appear to be an exceptionally happy couple. He insinuates himself into their lives, becomes obsessed with their relationship and attempts to seduce the wife, thereby causing destruction. One of the most elegant of Chabrol’s early works, the films presents an intriguing situation that develops with Hitchcockian undertones, even though the warped behaviour of the journalist remains somewhat of a puzzle. However Chabrol’s Peeping Tom camera is effectively used to suggest a study in voyeurism. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Carlo Ponti ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writer, Claude Chabrol, Marcel Matthieu ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen.
Cast: Stephane Audran, Jacques Charrier, Walter Reyer, Daniel Boulanger, Andre Badin.

results.title: Stress
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Bertucelli, Adolphe Viezzi, Adolphe Viezzi-Jean Ardy, Films de la Tour and FR3
results.brief_description:
Nathalie lives with her young daughter in Paris. She is attempting to rebuild her life after her fiance was killed in suspicious circumstances. She starts to receive noxious phone calls, both at home and at work. Then, the heart of an ox, marked with her daughter’s name is deposited on her doorsteps.

Credits: Producer, Adolphe Viezzi ; director, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; writers, Jean-Louis Bertucelli, Andre Grall, Alain Demouzon ; photography, Ricardo Aronovich ; music, Paul Misraki.
Cast: Carole Laure, Guy Marchand, Andre Dussolier, Anne Meson, Germaine Montero.

results.title: Projection Privee = Private Projection
results.brief_description:
Denis, a young director who is still traumatised by the violent death of his young lover, decides to make a film with about this tragic episode. One of the highlights of this film is the insight it gives into the actual mechanics of filmmaking.

Credits: Director, Francois Leterrier ; writer, Francois Leterrier, Madeleine Chapsal, Bernard Revon ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Serge Gainsbourg, Jean-Claude Vannier.
Cast: Francoise Fabian, Jean-Luc Bideau, Jane Birkin, Bulle Ogier, Jacques Weber.

results.title: Melodie En Sous-Sol = the Big Snatch (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
An ex-con sets up one last job and enlists the help of a younger crook to rob the Casino at Cannes. Everything goes according to plan, right up to the last minute until … A very standard caper film which gives one more opportunity to the trio Verneuil-Gabin-Audiard to send up the gangster genre with razor-sharp one-liners. Like his illustrious predecessors Henri Jeanson and Jacques Prevert, Audiard mixed classic French and slang and delighted in derision and ‘bons mots’, though his dialogue was coarser (a sign of the times) and more schocking. (…) Audiard’s witty, hard-hitting dialogue underpins much of the best popular French cinema from the late 1950s to the mid-1980s, notably his collaborations with Jean Gabin, for whom he wrote tailor-made dialogue.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Juranville ; director, Henri Verneuil ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Michel Magne.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Alain Delon, Maurice Biraud, Viviane Romance, Henri Virlojeux, Germaine Montero, Jean Carmet, Dora Doll.

results.title: Un Homme Qui Dort = a Man Who Sleeps
results.brief_description:
A student refuses to carry on with his studies and decides to live ‘in neutral time’ or at the limit of schizophrenia. Reference: Film Index International.

Credits: Director, Bernard Queysanne ; writers, Bernard Queysanne, Georges Perec ; photography, Bernard Zitzermann ; music, Philippe Drogoz, Eugenie Kuffler.
Cast: Jacques Spiesser, Ludmila Mikael.

results.title: Les Mysteres de Paris (TV Version) = the Mysteries of Paris
results.brief_description:
This version of Sue’s novel was originally conceived as a live-to-air production. Rodolphe de Sombreuil runs over a poor man in the streets and promises he will look after his young daughter. Sombreuil disguises himself as a working-class man and goes looking for Fleur de Marie who has been kidnapped by shady underworld characters. He is appalled by the squalor in which people live in the depressing working class slums.

Credits: Director, Marcel Cravenne ; writers, Claude Santelli ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Clotilde Joano, Marcel Bozzuffi, Jacques Dacqmine, Edmond Beauchamp, Georgette Anys, Jacques Marin, Francois Chaumette, Denise Gence, Veronique Silver, Maria Mauban, Claude Pieplu, Francois Maistre, Maria Meriko, Victor Lanoux, Clara Daquin.

results.title: Adorable Menteuse = Such an Adorable Liar
results.brief_description:
Juliette and Sophie share an apartment. Juliette is a garrulous 18-year-old girl who can’t go five minutes without telling a lie. She spies on her upstairs neighbour, a man of 40, pretending she is in love with him … until the day she really is. She vows to reform and speak nothing but the truth. But her reputation precedes her and her gentleman friend refuses to take anything she says seriously.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writers, Nina Companeez, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Jean Dalve.
Cast: Marina Vlady, Macha Meril, Ginette Letondal, Jean-Marc Bory, Michel Vitold, Jean-Francois Calve, Claude Nicot, Michel Lonsdale, Christian Alers.
